question.title: Cleared or overwritten Java printed lines stopping program
question.body:
Background

I am fairly new to non-scratch programming, and am working on a program in Java that mimics a screen by reading and printing a 2D array. The program currently prints out the array, waits for a specified duration, and then runs the lines System.out.flush(); System.out.print("\033[H"); The program successfully prints out the array and currently resets the cursor which makes the program print the new frame over the new one.

Problem

The problem is that the program slows down and stops after enough time has passed despite the fact that only the last frame is shown in the box if you scroll up or down. If I use a different IDE, it kills the process earlier because the output exceeds 2 MB. Also, each frame is fairly large and need to be updated rapidly.

Modules

The whole reason that I used text instead of a screen is because I cannot import many modules. My best guess is that I cannot use anything that requires you to access the computer's terminal to import, or are not immediately available on a free online IDE, but I don't know what exactly I can and can't import.

Intent and Question

The intent of this program is to have the most recent block of text be shown, and the previous blocks to be deleted without causing flashing.

Is there a way to overwrite the the output so that the code can run for a long time without reducing performance significantly?

-Clearing the output fully instead of overwriting the old frame makes the output flash pretty badly as the text prints.

Code

System.out.print("\033\143");

has the same issue.

System.out.println(new String(new char[50]).replace("\0", "\r\n"));

does not properly clear the output.

System.out.print("\033[2J");

Successfully stops the program from slowing down, but makes the output flash as it prints the next chunk of text.

Here is a sample of code that recreates the way that the array prints: (This is not the actual code, but mimics the final output of the code which is causing the problem)

public class Tester {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int rows = 50;
    int cols = 50;
    while (true) {
      for (int i = 0; i < rows; i++) {
        for (int g = 0; g < cols; g++) {
          System.out.print("a");
        }
        System.out.print("\n");
      }

      //thing that clears output
      System.out.flush();
      System.out.print("\033[H");
    }
  }
}
